content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is introduced, which excludes space-related income from gross income under a new section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a new section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, stating that gross income shall not include space-related income, defined as income derived from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from gross income, including services performed in outer space, interest, rent, and royalties related to space activities. Telecommunications services provided from earth orbit are excluded from this exemption. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from gross income, including services performed in outer space, interest, rent, and royalties related to space activities. Paragraph (1)(A)(ii) exceptions include telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transportation services to or from outer space before the enactment of the section. Wages received by employees are also exempt from Paragraph (1). The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from gross income, including services performed in outer space, interest, rent, and royalties related to space activities. Proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities is determined based on the expenses incurred in producing products in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes products manufactured in outer space from tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons. Production includes various methods like creation, fabrication, and processing. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes if produced at a facility owned by US individuals. Starting in 2015, the tax benefits will gradually decrease over time. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes if produced at a facility owned by US individuals. Tax benefits will gradually decrease after 2015. A similar rule applies to benefits under subsection (c). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes for products made in outer space at US-owned facilities. Tax benefits apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section is added to provide a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes for products made in outer space at US-owned facilities starting after December 31, 2005. A new section provides a credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes for products made in outer space at US-owned facilities starting after December 31, 2005. Qualified stock purchase criteria include average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, with over 70% derived from space-based business. Space-based business is defined as gross receipts mainly from space-related income. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes for products made in outer space at US-owned facilities starting after December 31, 2005. Qualified stock purchase criteria include average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, with over 70% derived from space-based business. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation must be acquired at its original issue by the taxpayer if the corporation is a qualified space company. The taxpayer must acquire qualified stock in a corporation at its original issue in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided. The stock must meet an active business requirement during the taxpayer's holding period. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to the purchase of its own stock by the corporation. Recapture rules apply in certain taxable years. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to qualified stock purchased by the taxpayer. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase, the tax for that year will increase by the decrease in credits under section 38. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The section allows for a space company investment credit under section 45I(a) as part of the general business credit. It does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The space company investment credit under section 45I(a) is included in the general business credit. Amendments are made to section 196 of the Code to incorporate this credit. The amendments made by this section apply to costs paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. Gross income excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. A qualified space corporation is defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses attributable to the active conduct of such business. This term excludes corporations providing services, products, or articles as described in section 139B(b)(2). The amendment excludes gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
